topics: Find the official USB-IF PD 3.1 specification or press release that states the PD 3.1 revision number and the Extended Power Range (EPR) limits (maximum wattage and maximum voltage).

document.query: "USB Power Delivery 3.1" specification maximum wattage maximum voltage revision number site:usb.org OR "Power Delivery 3.1" "USB-IF"
document.title: DEVELOPER UPDATE CONTACTS: Brad Saunders USB Promoter Group +1 503-264-0817
document.description: USB Power Delivery (USB PD) Revision 3.1 specification, a major update to enable delivering up to 240W

document.query: "USB Power Delivery 3.1" specification maximum wattage maximum voltage revision number site:usb.org OR "Power Delivery 3.1" "USB-IF"
document.title: GRL Enables Higher Wattage for USB Power Delivery 3.1 Testing
document.description: “The new USB Power Delivery 3.1 specification enables devices to supply power up to 240W over a USB- C® cable and connector, which will support a wider range of solutions with higher wattage requirements · beyond the previous limit 100W,” said Jeff Ravencraft, USB-IF President and COO.

document.query: "USB Power Delivery 3.1" specification maximum wattage maximum voltage revision number site:usb.org OR "Power Delivery 3.1" "USB-IF"
document.title: GRL Enables Higher Wattage for USB Power Delivery 3.1 Testing | USB-IF
document.description: Site sponsored by USB Implementers Forum, Inc., creators of USB technology

payload.query: "USB Power Delivery 3.1" specification maximum wattage maximum voltage revision number site:usb.org OR "Power Delivery 3.1" "USB-IF"

topics: Identify a specific commercial power adapter or charger that supports USB Power Delivery 3.1 (EPR) and obtain the manufacturer's product page, spec sheet, or documentation that explicitly confirms PD 3.1 support.

document.title: [FAQ] TPS65987D: New USB Type C PD 3.1 Spec enables Extended Power Range up to 240W (EPR) - Interface forum - Interface - TI E2E support forums
document.description: Recently the USB I/F (which manages the USB specification) approved and released an extension to the power range allowed across the Type C port and cable. Under this version of the specification, a port is allowed to negotiate a Power Deliver Object (PDO) of up to 240W (48V, 5A). This is enabled ...

document.title: The USB Power Delivery (PD) Specification — everything you need to know about USB-PD | Tom's Hardware
document.description: Released in 2021, USB PD 3.1 introduced Extended Power Range (EPR) that added three new fixed voltages. These were 28V, 36V and 48V.

document.title: USB PD EPR
document.description: An active contributor to the USB PD 3.1 specification which includes the Extended Power Range (EPR) definition, the ST solutions are among the first designs certified. ... IC, high-voltage protection devices, and a dedicated software stack. The design supports protocol fine · tuning and addresses ...

document.title: r/UsbCHardware on Reddit: Two years on from the USB PD 3.1 EPR annoucement allowing 240W charging and still only two laptops on the market have it (MBP 14 & 16)
document.description: PD 3.1 EPR has two major flaws: * It does not cover 330W used by the most powerful gaming notebooks * It requires 48V to deliver its specified maximum of 240W. The latter sounds like a non-problem, but it actually is.

document.title: USB PD 3.1: Power Delivery Tailored for Modern Applications - FSP Power Solution GmbH - AC/DC Power Supply Manufacturer
document.description: While the standard power range (SPR) covers up to 100W, the extended power range (EPR) of USB PD 3.1 supports devices requiring up to 240W (48V at 5A).

document.title: Eight PD 3.1 48V Fast Charging Protocol Chip: ChargerLAB Analysis - Chargerlab
document.description: It integrates two USB-C DRP DFP ports, capable of charging a PD host or connecting to USB-C devices for data transmission. Both UFP and the two DFP ports support the latest PD3.1 EPR specification, capable of delivering power output of 48V 5A (240W).

document.title: Technical Article USB Type-C® and USB Power Delivery: Designing
document.description: now called Standard Power Range (SPR), to flow in both directions. The latest USB PD 3.1 specification · increases the power range to 240W (48V, 5A), now called Extended Power Range (EPR), through a USB-C

document.title: DER-966 - 140 W USB PD 3.1 Extended Power Range Charger using PowiGaN-based InnoSwitch4-CZ, ClampZero and HiperPFS-5 | Power Integrations
document.description: 140 W USB PD 3.1 Extended Power Range (EPR) charger using PowiGaN-based InnoSwitch4-CZ (INN4077C-H182), ClampZero (CPZ1076M) and HiperPFS-5 (PFS5177F)

document.title: USB Power Delivery 3.2 Specification Updates and Certification Test Highlights
document.description: EPR Multiple Source Port has not yet been approved for certification testing. The USB PD 3.2 specification further enhances support for power supply stability, flexibility, and multi-port devices, and provides clear testing requirements for technologies such as FRS, AVS, power sharing, and EPR.

document.title: RDR-1002 - 140 W USB PD 3.1 Extended Power Range (EPR) Power Supply using InnoSwitch5-Pro (PowiGaN), HiperPFS-5 and Injoinic USB PD Controller | Power Integrations
document.description: 140 W USB PD 3.1 power adapter with 15 V - 28 V EPR adjustable output using PowiGaN-based InnoSwitch5-Pro (INN5377F-H905) and HiperPFS-5 (PFS5277F) in conjunction with Injoinic™ USB PD controller (IP2756)

payload.mandate: Find the USB-C Power Delivery 3.1 specification details: maximum wattage, maximum voltage, and revision number. Also find one product that supports this specification and confirm with the manufacturer's documentation. Provide all specifications with citation URLs.

topics: Find the official USB-IF PD 3.1 specification or press release that states the PD 3.1 revision number and the Extended Power Range (EPR) limits (maximum wattage and maximum voltage).

Identify a specific commercial power adapter or charger that supports USB Power Delivery 3.1 (EPR) and obtain the manufacturer's product page, spec sheet, or documentation that explicitly confirms PD 3.1 support.

payload.query: "USB Power Delivery 3.1" specification maximum wattage maximum voltage revision number site:usb.org OR "Power Delivery 3.1" "USB-IF"
